segments.text: two or three years or something, from Spain.
And he would have a question or some sample material that he wanted us to analyze.
And the last time he called, they had selected a bentonite to use in their nuclear

waste science and he said this is a spanish bentonite but it doesn't have the colloidal properties that your miami bentonite has and we don't know if we dare use it or not and he said it and we analyzed it and told him why it wasn't colloidal it had the chemical properties of bentonite

but it didn't have the physical properties and the reason was that the tiny little crystals of clay had not been fully dispersed and they were present in little little lumps of actually silt-sized lumps which is still pretty small
And they didn't behave colloidally, and it should serve their purpose very well.
And actually, we use that example in this book that we're now putting out.
So it turned out to be a research contribution as well as a... And he, as I say, was a civil engineer.
and other good civil engineering students.
The best, probably the best one that I should remember from my own professional point of view is Douglas Darrell Schultz.
Darrell Schultz was from downtown, small town between here and Houston, German community down there.
And Darryl was in the Corps.
And I used to hire undergraduates and still like to hire undergraduates to work with us some.
And he worked with us some in the lab when he was in the Corps and come in and had his uniform on from time to time.
And finally, he decided, well, he'd do his master's degree.
And I told him, that's fine.
I have a friend in Germany.
whom I had developed a working relationship through this book publishing cycle that I'd gotten into, Udo Svirtman, and I said, he'd probably be glad to have you come over and work something with him.
And so he did, and he was the first in our lab to use the magnet
to take iron compounds out of soil.
And we knew this process had been developed, but we hadn't brought it down to a laboratory scale.
He used a magnet over in engineering, actually, to do that.
And Darrell Schultz then applied and received a von Humboldt scholarship and went to Germany and worked with my colleague Schwertmann and got his doctor's degree there.
And he's on the faculty at Purdue University and has been there for several years and has been very successful there.
And he and I are co-editors on this last book, which is gratifying.
Of all the students you've had, reckon what percentage are in academia, what percentage are in government, what percentage are out in private industry?
They're scattered throughout the three different areas.
I guess academia would maybe have a slight edge.
Some are consultants.
Just last week I called Hugh Durham, and Hugh got his master's here.
He's a South Texas boy and married a young Greek lady when he was in the military.
And they were here, and his children were small, and he was pressed by finances and didn't get a PhD, and went with a clay company in Georgia.
And now he's in Gonzales with the Southern Clay Products Company, and he's marketing clay products for them.
And I called him last week and talked to him, and he was in Memphis, north of Memphis, when I caught him in the car over there.
For a master's student, he's done well.
And down through the years, could you tell much difference between the preparation, once they were in your class, of the engineers, the geoscientists, the ag people?
Was there much difference between how capable they were to do the work in their course?
They tend to have a better developed background mathematically.
in engineering.
And they tend to have a better background chemically in soil science.
And those are the main differences.
And as time goes on,
They blend, but in general, it's pretty hard for people who never, engineers are taught chemistry, but they don't use it day to day like we have to use it.
And therefore, that's kind of a hurdle that they have to gradually work over.
But the beauty of this course, like I had a student from India who was in civil engineering.
He was a real promoter for the course.
He recruited students from us over there.
And he's now, I think, with a consulting firm.
But he was really a spark plug at whatever he did.
And it was because he could see through this.
And our ultimate customer is really the public.
And he was one who saw the full breadth of that.
And he had to do very engineering type of work when he was here and worked quite a lot with me mineralogically and with my research associate.
But when he got over there, he had to apply it in a totally different way to highway instability and things like that.
But he went out then.
to serve in the public.
And he's the second engineer that I've had that had an international background who went out, the first one went with a state highway.
And these, my point is that we can't very often get a chance to help much with roads and foundations because our research is not
We're not tied as closely to that.
But these students, they take this right out into the field.
And so that's among the more gratifying experience I've had with students, realizing that Texas is plagued with millions of acres of very reactive clay soils.
And, you know, if you drive the streets of this community, you know that painfully.
Well, even today I was talking with one of my colleagues in Extension about how we could do something to help handle the urban scene, not just the rural scene, but the urban scene.
as to how to better utilize these soils and stabilize them and get the water to flow where it should and not where it does.
And being able to work with this diverse group has permitted us to reach out quite a bit to them.
In these students and their effort, I have the impression that Asian students are extremely diligent.
Can you generalize about the diligence of students by their background?
Just their determination, their effort?
It is true that the Asian students do tend to be very diligent.
At the Masters and PhD level, the students in general are more motivated.
So having to prod students is not our usual circumstance.
Now, there's a lot of difference.
I've had not many students from Japan, although I've had a few, but I've had some postdocs from Japan.
And they are very methodical, and they can work on the most ragged problem, and their consistency and persistence they can deal with.
whereas Americans would probably not have the patience.
But coming up as they have, and as it happens, Japanese soils are volcanic soils, very disorderly and very difficult to deal with.
They made progress, and I've had the privilege of working with three different Japanese.
Have you ever had any...
events that obviously showed some kind of awkwardness between some students because of their, the history of their countries.
A student from Greece and Turkey working side by side or Korea and Japan working side, any of that ever?
I've thought about that many times, and that's really a rare thing.
I had a student came in from South Africa, actually, he was a postdoc here.
And he said when he got here, he said, you know, it was quite an experience to come from South Africa and come in through South America.
Said we kind of went from the black to the brown.
He said, that was really a jolt to my wife and I.
And he was not prejudiced.
He was a white child.
Yes, he was white.
And he was very diligent, very capable, very efficient.
And it wasn't long until Abu Sinkai from Uganda, who's very African,
They were just exchanging views.
And so it's sort of a mystery to me that people have trouble that they do when I see these guys working together.
What about any awkwardness of male-female, a Muslim, a woman from a Muslim background dressing in a fashion that might not be acceptable back home or something or other?
I don't believe I've had a Muslim woman.
I remember when I went to Saudi Arabia and I met my friends from over there.
They came out in their white attire.
And I just commented, you know, all this grand welcoming beginning and all this workshop we were going to have.
They had brought in people from all the neighboring Arab countries, which I found later they had to pay their way to get them to come.
And I just said privately at lunch or something, it's a mysterious thing I've observed here.
You all have such a, Riyadh is growing and thriving, and yet there are no women.
I just don't know how you've managed all this.
They sure didn't come back with any quick answers.
But even then I could see these young ladies that they were beginning to educate with their briefcases and going to the record shops and that music and things.
But I haven't had any, I've had, now I did have a young woman, now that you mention that,
The poorest country neighbor to India on the east.
It's in the wetlands.
I think it's Bangladesh.
She was my class, and she's Muslim.

But she said, when I discussed that type of thing with her privately, she said, well, when I first came, I wore my attire one day, but said, you know, it seemed to be sort of a problem, so I haven't been wearing it anymore.
Her father was a civil engineer.
And they were actually originally from India, I think, and they were working in that part of the world.
But she was very bright and very capable and did well in the course.
So I was pleased, because I've always had a particular empathy for the women in that part of the world.
Have you ever had any student of any sort
give you some kind of hokum kind of excuse that they can't do something or other because of, or they need special consideration because of?
I had a sabbatical person from Egypt who was devout, is devout Muslim.
And the thing that he did that I, he didn't press this on us, but every so many times a day,
he rolled out his mat and did his prayers in the laboratory.
Oh, so he really did.
And I made a point not to go into the laboratory when he was prayer time for him.
But he combined the two.
He was highly motivated in his religion.
He worked as hard as any man I've ever known and did a lot of good work.
But he was the most orthodox person I think I've ever worked with.
Very pleasant, but he drew the line.
All right, this is to the typist.
This is not an editorial note and you don't need to include it in the typed version.

The best excuse I've ever gotten as an example of goofiness was from an Aggie who told me that his first day, his freshman course, his grandfather was really sick and that he might not make it through the semester.
And I said, you're not teasing?
He said, no, it's really serious.
I said, well, gee, I hope it's not terminal.
He said, oh, yeah, yeah, he's probably not going to make it.
I said, well, keep me informed and we'll try to do the best we can.
He was still serious, or so it looked.
And when he got to the door, he turned his back to me and he said, in fact, sir, it's almost certain he's going to die the first day of deer season.
So I use that as my best example ever.
All right, now take me through your research.
What were you working on when you got here?
And what were your research efforts and projects and so forth?
It could take a long time.
I don't know how much of that you want.
When I was in Auburn,
University in Alabama, we were defining soils.
We were analyzing samples of soils that had never been analyzed.
And we had a new x-ray machine, and we were just getting these basic data.
And so that was the focus of what we did.
Excuse me a moment.
I guess I'll take this off.
Or should I?
When I came to Texas, Kunze had done quite a lot of characterization of the mineralogy of Texas soils.
He's always done some more, but he had studied samples of the Houston Black, which is the state soil, and the Lufkin, which is a local soil, and the Beaumont, which is an acid soil they grow rice on.
He had done the general mineralogy of them.
reasonably well, and he was very methodical.
He always had a good technician, and they did things very methodically, and so I had files of data, and have often gone back and pulled those out and compared, and that's been very effective.
So I began to look for other things.
The space era and the environmental eras have been factors that have influenced us.
I had a student, David Carty, who came in as an undergraduate, and he wanted to do a
a problem with library kind of study on how to contain a nuclear explosion out of a generating plant.
Now, this is a long way back.
We were still way back in the old State Chemist's Building, and a whole lot of things have happened in the country since then, and nobody had witnessed stuff.
a nuclear event.

And whenever we made contact, and David did this as his project, with a nuclear branch of government, they not only didn't want to share anything with him, they sort of scolded him for even asking the question.
And he

he had the idea that, well, someday there's going to be a meltdown and if we study the soils in the area, that we could make a berm around the site and we could contain whatever was there if we chose the soils correctly.
And this would be a significant deterrent to the spreading of radioactive materials.
As I say, he did what he could, but it was an unpopular topic.
They didn't want to talk to him about it.
But in the intervening years, we found out how prophetic his thoughts were.
He was kind of a radical student, in a sense, talking about this sort of thing.
But we know about Three Mile Island.
We know about Chernobyl.
And we know that that kind of information is really good thinking.
And by the way, that young man is a consultant here in Bryan now.
He works out of Bryan.
So he's still pursuing environmental problems.
So we did work.
That was not a very in-depth endeavor, but that was one thing.
Another one that comes to mind that's more novel than anything else, and that is
I had a student who worked as an undergraduate helping in the lab part-time, and he wanted to do some research.

And it had happened there had been a young lady who was from the geography department, and she came in one day and she had about a dozen samples that she had picked up while she was touring near Pericatine Volcano in Mexico.
She said, the crop's doing terrible there.
These people can grow a good crop of corn.
What's the problem?
And she said, here are these samples.
Well, you look at them and tell me about it.
Well, I felt very humbled at that point because I didn't have any idea that I could do much looking at those samples to tell her why the corn didn't grow well in Pericotine.
But she left them and she told me she would check back.

And so I told this young man who was working with me, I said, now you want to do a piece of research, and we're doing soil mineralogy, would you take the clay out of those 12 samples and we'll x-ray it and see what it is?
He did.
And we x-rayed them and it was the poorest set of x-ray patterns I think I ever saw.
Out of the whole set we had two that had some small peaks on them.
The others were just lines, just jiggle lines.
Those days we had long strip charts.
And that was, well, then came a student from oceanography, Tom McKee.
And Tom
really liked to work with electron microscopes.
And that, he came to me because he thought I could use it for the electron mic work.
And so he took those and looked at them, and that was before the, I believe it was the 10th International Soil Congress in Moscow.
And Tom McKee looked at those little glass particles, which is mostly what those soils were, volcanic glass, and found little spots in them
which we realized were hallucite, a particular kind of clay that forms in many soils and in volcanic soils particularly.
And then we went to the other instruments, infrared and so on, and characterized what they were further.
And I gave that paper in Moscow and it's published in the proceedings of that conference.
From that, we had analyzed some soil from Guatemala.

There's an aggie from Guatemala who used to come here every year because he had children in school here, and he would bring some samples with him, and he again would ask me questions like, I want to know if this will make good soil for growing tomatoes, which
I wasn't exactly the person that should have been handling that kind of question.
But he would also, in his position as an alumnus, he would leave me the samples and he'll say, all right, you send me the results.
And Dr. Bloodworth, that's the only time that I can remember Dr. Bloodworth saying, would you like to meet this gentleman and help him out?
And so and so I did.
And we had found this one soil that had a lot of aloesite in it from Guatemala, volcanic soil.
Well, some of it was spherical.
And clays are making up of layers, and there's, if you distort a layer, it tends to roll and make a cylinder.
And most all the holosite in the world that we knew about in those days was tubular.
And here we found spheres.
And so the clave scientists from all around wanted to know why spheres.
In the glass from pericotine, we saw these spheres forming in bubbles at the microscopic level, at the micron level.
And no one has ever refuted that, and that grew out of the
undergraduate student's inquiry, the lady, the geography student bringing the sample from Mexico, and then I went later to the pericotine and sampled the soil again when I was in there.
So that was, those were kind of isolated parts of research.
But those were projects that you got involved in as a result of the student.
Right.
But what were your pet projects when you got here and how did they, what else, what did that lead to?
Well, the history of clay mineralogy and soils for quite a long time was potassium chemistry.
We all know that you've got nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium.
That's what the gardener puts on and makes fertilizer.
So potassium, there's a lot of it applied.
It's an expensive fertilizer amendment.
And clays have potassium in the structure in some cases.
And so we were always trying to figure out why some clays held
why does the Houston black clay hold potassium effectively, or why it releases it?
Well, that work was really the
what we were pursuing whenever I mentioned Frank Hans earlier, that's the way that turned out up there.
That the shortage of potassium was what they were trying to deal with, and the soil test would say they needed to apply soil potassium fertilizer, but the plant didn't respond that way.
And in his work, we found that, well, there is enough mica in a certain fraction of that soil that it is releasing some potassium.
And so that correlated with the available potassium to the plant.
And we published that work.
So that was one of my areas of interest, a subject much worked on by many soil scientists.
What was next?
Well, a lot of things that come to us in research are kind of coincidental.
I was and am interested in iron oxides, and whenever I got to using the new microscope here, and growing out of Daryl Schultz's work to some degree, we had the tools to deal with iron oxides.
And in this regional project, we want to deal with them.
One of the basic problems with soils is that they may be chemically controlled reasonably well, but we cannot physically control them very well.
And that is still a persistent problem, as we mentioned earlier.
And so I wanted to analyze the iron oxides in some of the soils from the states and the regional group, as well as in Texas, and see what
what there was about them that made the soil behave differently when we have quite a lot of iron oxide in them.
The two major aggregating agents in soils are iron oxides and organic matter.
being a mineralogist, I was looking at the iron oxide.
After all, the red clays of Georgia are rather well-structured.
And many of the red soils of the southeastern United States, they're rather well-structured.
But the gray soils of Texas are not very well-structured.
And so I began to look at them.
And from that, I realized with the instrument that we have that
While clays in soil, again, they're layered, they tend to be smooth.
And there's not much friction between layered structures, graphite, clay, and so on.
But these iron oxides are like little cockleburs or something, only they're little crystal ends.
And even within the last few weeks, I've had to correct my Midwestern colleagues who said there are no crystal faces on iron oxides.
They think that they're disorganized.
But only when you magnify them about a third of a million times or more can you realize that really they're composed of numerous little crystal faces that are some micron in size.
That's, one would never know that without good instrumentation.
And so I think that's a significant finding.
And I teach it now.
So iron oxides.
I got interested while I was on sabbatical.
There was a young woman, Shirley Turner, a slightly deformed young lady.
sort of a strange structural deal, but a very good scientist.
And she was working on manganese oxides, and this was a geology group that I was associated with, and she did a very nice dissertation on manganese oxides.
So when I came back from sabbatical, I got a copy of her dissertation, and then I began to look, and a lot of these soils in Texas have little black nodules in them
which are manganese oxide.
And so I started characterizing those.
And she brought me into contact with the electron microscopic techniques for doing that, and which I, of course, learned, studied there.
So in our work with reclamation, which is, I worked about 10 years collaboratively with Lloyd Hosner, who's a soil chemist, and some other people, and had sabbatical people come in
And we worked about how to convert overburden into soil, and what would be good and what would be bad.
And one of the things that we found in that was that there are these black coatings on some of the rock that were exposed by mining.
And we identified that as toterokite,
manganese oxide that was
